Package org.logevents.config

Class DefaultLogEventConfigurator

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.logevents.config.DefaultLogEventConfigurator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    LogEventConfigurator
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DefaultTestLogEventConfigurator
    public class DefaultLogEventConfigurator
extends Object
implements LogEventConfigurator

    You can extends this class and put the classname your configurator in META-INF/services/org.logevents.LogEventConfigurator override the default behavior.

    Default implementation of LogEventConfigurator which reads the logging configuration from logevents.properties-files in the directory specified by the system property logevents.directory (defaults to current working directory). This class will by default load logevents-profile.properties and logevents.properties, where based on getProfiles(). logevents.properties files in profile takes precedence over default logevents.properties files. Files in configuration directory takes precedence over files in classpath and are automatically scanned for changes.

    logevents.properties could look like this (applyConfigurationProperties(org.logevents.LogEventFactory, java.util.Map<java.lang.String, java.lang.String>)): 

     root=LEVEL [observer1,observer2]
 root.observer.observer3=LEVEL

 logger.com.example=LEVEL [observer]
 includeParent.com.example=true|false

 logger.com.noisy=NONE

 observer.name=ObserverClass
 observer.name.property=value

    By default, observers named observer.console ConsoleLogEventObserver and observer.file FileLogEventObserver are created. By default, the root root logger is set to INFO console. Use LEVEL `NONE` to turn off logging for a logger

    Log configuration can also be loaded from environment variables:

    • LOGEVENTS_STATUS: StatusEvent.StatusLevel for internal diagnostics
    • LOGEVENTS_ROOT=<LEVEL [logger1,logger2,...]>: The root level and observer, for example DEBUG console
    • LOGEVENTS_LOGGER_ORG_EXAMPLE=<LEVEL [logger1,logger2,...]>: The level and observer for the case-insensitive logger category, for example DEBUG console
    • LOGEVENTS_ROOT_OBSERVER_<observerName>=<LEVEL>: Add a global observer, for example LOGEVENTS_ROOT_OBSERVER_STATS=DEBUG
    • LOGEVENT_OBSERVER_<observerName>=<ClassName>: initialize observer
    • LOGEVENT_OBSERVER_<observerName>_PROPERTY: observer configuration

    This class is designed with subclassing in mind. When subclassing, configure(LogEventFactory) should probably be overridden

    Author:
    Johannes Brodwall

      • loadConfigurationProperties

        public Map<String,​String> loadConfigurationProperties()
        Reads logevents.properties from classpath and filesystem. getProfiles() is used to determine logevents-profile.properties files names. Files from profile take precedence over default logevents.properties and files from filesystem takes precedence over files from classpath.
        Returns:
        A merged Properties object with all relevant files merged together

      • getProfiles

        protected List<String> getProfiles()
        Uses system properties 'profiles', 'profile' and 'spring.profiles.active' (in order of preference) to determine which profiles are active in the current environment. The profiles are split on ","
        Returns:
        the activated profiles for the current JVM as a list of strings

      • loadPropertiesFromFiles

        protected Map<String,​String> loadPropertiesFromFiles​(List<String> configurationFileNames)
        Loads all properties files relevant for the argument set of profiles from classpath and current working directory.
        Parameters:
        configurationFileNames - the file names to load
        Returns:
        Properties with the configuration of all files merged together

      • applyConfigurationProperties

        public void applyConfigurationProperties​(LogEventFactory factory,
                                         Map<String,​String> configuration)
        Configures observers and loggers from properties. Observers have properties on the format observers.prefix=ClassName and loggers have properties on the format logger.log.name=LEVEL observer1,observer2. LogEventObserver class names must be fully qualified (e.g. observer.mine=com.example.MyObserver) unless the observer is in org.logevents.observers package (e.g. observer.slack=SlackLogEventObserver).
        Parameters:
        factory - The LogEventFactory that this configurator should configure
        configuration - The merged configuration that should be applied to the factory
